paragraphs.text: He says, Sisyphus is the perfect model for us, since he has no illusions about his pointless situation and yet revolts against the circumstances. With every descent of the rock he makes a conscious decision to give it another go. He keeps pushing that rock and recognises that this is what his existence is all about: to be truly alive, to keep pushing.
paragraphs.name: 3dfd

paragraphs.text: This absurd sensitivity is the result of a conflict. On the one hand we make reasonable plans for our lives, and on the other hand we are confronted with an unpredictable world which does not comply with our ideas.
At this point clinging to our reasonable models would not be reasonable anymore. We would be forced to live in denial, we would have to believe.
paragraphs.name: 7c7d

paragraphs.text: 2. Reject eternal freedom: Instead of enslaving ourselves to eternal models we should hold on to reason, but be aware of its limitations and apply it flexibly to the situation at hand — or put simply: we should find freedom here and now, not in eternity.
paragraphs.name: 47c4

paragraphs.text: He says, Sisyphus is the perfect model for us, since he has no illusions about his pointless situation and yet revolts against the circumstances. With every descent of the rock he makes a conscious decision to give it another go. He keeps pushing that rock and recognises that this is what his existence is all about: to be truly alive, to keep pushing.
paragraphs.name: 3dfd

paragraphs.text: He says, Sisyphus is the perfect model for us, since he has no illusions about his pointless situation and yet revolts against the circumstances. With every descent of the rock he makes a conscious decision to give it another go. He keeps pushing that rock and recognises that this is what his existence is all about: to be truly alive, to keep pushing.
paragraphs.name: 3dfd

paragraphs.text: 1. Permanent revolution: We should constantly revolt against the circumstances of our existence and thus keep the absurd alive. We should never accept defeat, not even death, even though we know it can’t be avoided in the long run. Permanent rebellion is the only way to be present in the world.
paragraphs.name: e588

paragraphs.text: The Myth of the Individual
paragraphs.name: 6d44

paragraphs.text: Most (I’ve yet to find an exception) philosophers and students of theology, regardless of the brand, seek to explain the joy or futility of existence as something that isolates the individual from the group. I suggest we examine our experience as a member of a group (humans) and not as a separate…

e56fd3dbd8bb.title: There is something profound in that statement, “to be truly alive, to keep pushing.”

paragraphs.text: There is something profound in that statement, “to be truly alive, to keep pushing.” Or better yet, “to be truly alive…keep pushing.” Reject the hopeless part, live, and keep pushing!
paragraphs.name: de28

paragraphs.text: Is that misrepresenting the Concept?
paragraphs.name: f08e

694269b9fa2a.title: Camus’ rebellion is less a rebellion against an authority or political regime but a revolt against…

paragraphs.text: Camus’ rebellion is less a rebellion against an authority or political regime but a revolt against the hopelessness or senselessness of our existence. And this revolt cannot be won but is still worth upholding as a sign of being alive. One might perhaps say that this is not about a struggle for survival but a struggle to be alive.
paragraphs.name: 3b57

ed260048a74e.title: But then, why is it that only a handful of those rebels is being rewarded while the majority is…

paragraphs.text: Putting less emphasis on eternal plans in favour of the present situation may be a very uplifting idea, don’t you think? Camus himself was actually a very fun-loving man, and if I understand his concept correctly, the idea of abandoning long-term illusions could serve as a relief and source of joy.

paragraphs.text: Been feeling this way all week, couldn’t put it into words, aren’t we all a little of this absurd human? “An absurd human knows about his mortality and yet doesn’t accept it, knows about the limitation of his reasoning, yet still holds it dear, feels the pleasure and pain of his experiences and yet tries to take in as many as possible.”
paragraphs.name: 48f1

d25f3e691a5a.title: Well put, Mike! When it comes to car accidents… the most absurd thing is how Camus died.

paragraphs.text: Well put, Mike! When it comes to car accidents… the most absurd thing is how Camus died.
But apart from those big wake-up calls, don’t you think that it is a huge part of growing up to understand, that so much in our lives is actually unpredictable and outside of our control?
paragraphs.name: 9ebf

paragraphs.text: Thank you Imogen! Yes, and in addition to the focus on the here and now I really like Camus’ idea to resist the temptation to appease or even eliminate the conflict between our plans the world but rather cultivate and cherish it as the essential trait of life. So let’s keep making plans without being afraid of life’s forces that might push us elsewhere!
paragraphs.name: a09a

290212192395.title: I suppose it’s blasphemous to take issue with Camus, but I don’t accept the premise — “the world is…

paragraphs.text: I suppose it’s blasphemous to take issue with Camus, but I don’t accept the premise — “the world is unpredictable.” The world is quite predictable, all cause and effect. It is man who is not, acts and reacts unreasonably, primarily out of emotion — anger, fear, love, desperation, etc.
